terms.definition: Software as a Service - a cloud-based software delivery model where applications are hosted by a provider and accessed via the internet
A centralized repository of information, documentation, and resources that provides answers to common questions and solutions to problems
A system that tracks and manages changes to documents or code over time, allowing users to access previous versions and maintain an audit trail
A single, unified storage location where all documents and files are kept, eliminating scattered or siloed information systems
Application Programming Interface - a set of rules and protocols that allows different software applications to communicate and share data with each other
A chronological record of all changes, access, and activities performed on documents or systems for compliance and tracking purposes
A security method that restricts document or system access based on a user's role within an organization
Pre-designed document formats that provide a standardized structure for creating consistent documentation across an organization
Software features that enable multiple users to work together on documents simultaneously, including commenting, editing, and approval workflows
A user interface designed to work effectively on mobile devices like smartphones and tablets, ensuring accessibility from any location
Data analysis tools that monitor and measure adherence to regulations and standards, helping identify gaps and generate compliance reports
International Organization for Standardization standard 45001 - a global standard for occupational health and safety management systems
The ability of software to connect with external databases containing current laws and regulations to provide automatic updates and alerts
A software system designed to store, organize, track, and manage electronic documents and digital images throughout their lifecycle
Isolated software or storage systems that don't communicate with each other, creating barriers to information sharing and collaboration
